Simplex

Posted on 2020-02-07 Edited on 2020-02-18

Simplex is the first systematically method for solving linear program via a sequence of Gaussian eliminations. It was invented by George Dantzig in 1947 [1]. Algebraically, it converts the linear program from one slack form into to an equivalent one whose objective value does not decrease and possibly increase. It keeps going until the optimal is reached. Geometrically, it is a greedy search strategy that moves from a vertex of the feasible region to another one, with the objective value at the new vertex as least as good as or possibly improved over the previous one. It is an exponential algorithm, although most of time it does a lot better. In this blog we walk through a simple example to illustrate this.

In this case we are operating a factory with two products. Both product have 1 unit of profit. Making the products needs to use two kind of machine. Product one uses 1 hour of machine one and product two uses 2 hours of machine one. Further, product one uses 2 hours of machine two and product two uses 1 hour of machine two. Both machines operate at most 6 hours each day. We want to maximize our profit:

max⁡x1+x2s.t.x1+2x2≤62x1+x2≤6x1,x2≥0\begin{aligned} &\max & x_1 + x_2 \\ &s.t. & x_1 + 2x_2 \le 6 \\ & & 2x_1 + x_2 \le 6 \\ & & x_1, x_2 \ge 0 \end{aligned} ​maxs.t.​x1​+x2​x1​+2x2​≤62x1​+x2​≤6x1​,x2​≥0​

It can be represented concisely in matrix form:

max⁡cTxs.t.Ax≤bx≥0\begin{aligned} &\max & c^T x \\ &s.t. & A x \le b \\ & & x \ge 0 \end{aligned} ​maxs.t.​cTxAx≤bx≥0​

where

A=[1221],b=[66],c=[11],x=[x1x2],\begin{aligned} A = \left[ \begin{matrix} 1 & 2 \\ 2 & 1 \end{matrix} \right], \quad b = \left[ \begin{matrix} 6 \\ 6 \end{matrix} \right], \quad c = \left[ \begin{matrix} 1 \\ 1 \end{matrix} \right], \quad x = \left[ \begin{matrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \end{matrix} \right], \end{aligned} A=[12​21​],b=[66​],c=[11​],x=[x1​x2​​],​

We call the set of points that satisfy the constraints of the optimization problem the feasible region

P={x:Ax≤b,x≥0}P = \{x : Ax \le b, x \ge 0\} P={x:Ax≤b,x≥0}

It is obvious that the optimal is obtained at (2,2)(2, 2)(2,2), which gives the objective value 444. It is a vertex of the feasible region.

Slack Form

In general, it might not be obvious what the optimal point is. But if the elements of bbb are non-negative, the origin is a feasible point, from which we can begin our search. To make the search easier, we are going to introduce an additional number of variables, the slack variables s1,s2s_1, s_2s1​,s2​ and zzz that correspond to the constraints and objective value.

z=x1+x2s1=6−x1−2x2s2=6−2x1−x2\begin{aligned} z = & & x_1 &+x_2 \\ s_1 = &6 & -x_1 &-2x_2 \\ s_2 = &6 & -2x_1 &-x_2 \\ \end{aligned} z=s1​=s2​=​66​x1​−x1​−2x1​​+x2​−2x2​−x2​​

rewrite the optimization into slack form:

max⁡x1+x2=zs.t.x1+2x2+s1=62x1+x2+s2=6x1,x2,s1,s2≥0\begin{aligned} &\max & x_1 &+x_2 & & &= z\\ &s.t. & x_1 &+2x_2 &+s_1 & &= 6 \\ & & 2x_1 &+x_2 & &+s_2 &= 6 \\ & & x_1, &x_2, &s_1 &,s_2 &\ge 0 \end{aligned} ​maxs.t.​x1​x1​2x1​x1​,​+x2​+2x2​+x2​x2​,​+s1​s1​​+s2​,s2​​=z=6=6≥0​

They are called slacks variables because they correspond how much slack you have in the inequalities in the original problem. For this slack form, we also call s1s_1s1​ and s2s_2s2​ basic variables, and the original variables non-basic variables.

Now the feasible region FFF is considered as the intersection of the two subspaces

F={x:Ax=b}∩{x≥0}F = \{x : Ax = b \} \cap \{ x \ge 0 \} F={x:Ax=b}∩{x≥0}

We can represent the LP in slack form even more concisely in a table:

1210∣62101∣61100∣0\begin{aligned} 1 && 2 && 1 && 0 && \mid 6 \\ 2 && 1 && 0 && 1 && \mid 6 \\ \hline 1 && 1 && 0 && 0 && \mid 0 \\ \end{aligned} 121​​211​​100​​010​​∣6∣6∣0​​

where the last column denotes the objective function. This example has a trivial starting point : (0,0,6,6)(0, 0, 6, 6)(0,0,6,6). It is called a basic solution in which all non-basic variables are set to zero. It can be read from the tabular form: the identity matrix correspond to basic variables, and (s1,s2)=b(s_1, s_2) = b(s1​,s2​)=b.

Pivoting

Look at the original LP:

max⁡x1+x2=zs.t.x1+2x2+s1=62x1+x2+s2=6x1,x2,s1,s2≥0\begin{aligned} &\max & x_1 &+x_2 & & &= z\\ &s.t. & x_1 &+2x_2 &+s_1 & &= 6 \\ & & 2x_1 &+x_2 & &+s_2 &= 6 \\ & & x_1, &x_2, &s_1 &,s_2 &\ge 0 \end{aligned} ​maxs.t.​x1​x1​2x1​x1​,​+x2​+2x2​+x2​x2​,​+s1​s1​​+s2​,s2​​=z=6=6≥0​

As we would like to maximize the objective, we would like to increase the value of x1x_1x1​ or x2x_2x2​ as much as possible. Suppose we just increase one variable at a time. For example, we can increase variable x1x_1x1​ and keep the value of x2x_2x2​ to be 000.

How much can we increase x1x_1x1​? After increasing x1x_1x1​, we need to maintain the inequality constraints:

x1+s1=62x1+s2=6x_1 + s_1 = 6 \\ 2 x_1 + s_2 = 6 x1​+s1​=62x1​+s2​=6

The values of s1s_1s1​ and s2s_2s2​ decrease as x1x_1x1​ increases. By they can be drop below 000. The maximum possible increases of x1x_1x1​ is bounded by 6/2=36 / 2 = 36/2=3. If we set x1=3x_1 = 3x1​=3, s1=6−x1=3s_1 = 6 - x_1 = 3s1​=6−x1​=3 and s2=6−2x1=0s_2 = 6 - 2x_1 = 0s2​=6−2x1​=0.

Note that x1x_1x1​ increases from 000 to 333 and s2s_2s2​ decreases from 666 to 000. This process is called pivoting.

How do we perform pivoting in the tabular form? By the replacement we have just performed – normalizing the second row, and using it to eliminate all other elements in the first column.

Recall the original table:

1210∣62101∣61100∣0\begin{aligned} 1 && 2 && 1 && 0 && \mid 6 \\ 2 && 1 && 0 && 1 && \mid 6 \\ \hline 1 && 1 && 0 && 0 && \mid 0 \\ \end{aligned} 121​​211​​100​​010​​∣6∣6∣0​​

We divide the second row by a factor of 2 to normalize it, and subtract the first and third row by the second row

03/21−1/2∣311/201/2∣301/20−1/2∣−3\begin{aligned} 0 && 3/2 && 1 && -1/2 && \mid 3 \\ 1 && 1/2 && 0 && 1/2 && \mid 3 \\ \hline 0 && 1/2 && 0 && -1/2 && \mid -3 \\ \end{aligned} 010​​3/21/21/2​​100​​−1/21/2−1/2​​∣3∣3∣−3​​

Observe the first two rows of the tabular form:

03/21−1/2∣311/201/2∣3\begin{aligned} 0 && 3/2 && 1 && -1/2 && \mid 3 \\ 1 && 1/2 && 0 && 1/2 && \mid 3 \\ \end{aligned} 01​​3/21/2​​10​​−1/21/2​​∣3∣3​

If we set x2=0x_2 = 0x2​=0 and s2=0s_2 = 0s2​=0, the constraints they implies becomes

s1=3x1=3s_1 = 3 \\ x_1 = 3 s1​=3x1​=3

Again the unity columns correspond to non-zero elements and we can read the solution from the tabular form.

Correctness of Pivoting

Before we continue our search on the tabular form, we need to show that pivoting is correct in the sense that, after pivoting, the tabular form represents the same optimization.

In particular, we need to guarantee that the feasible regions are the same and the objective function are equivalent defined on the feasible regions.

We focus on the extended matrix that represents the constraints:

Aˉ=[A,b]=[1210∣62101∣6]\bar A = [A, b] = \left[\begin{aligned} 1 && 2 && 1 && 0 && \mid 6 \\ 2 && 1 && 0 && 1 && \mid 6 \\ \end{aligned}\right] Aˉ=[A,b]=[12​​21​​10​​01​​∣6∣6​]

FACT 1. Doing a row replacement on Aˉ\bar AAˉ does not change FFF, where row replacement is defined as

Aˉ[i:]←Aˉ[i:]+k⋅Aˉ[j:]\bar A[i: ] \leftarrow \bar A[i: ] + k \cdot \bar A[j: ] Aˉ[i:]←Aˉ[i:]+k⋅Aˉ[j:]

i.e., adding kkk times the jjj-th row to the iii-th row, for i≠j,k∈Ri \neq j, k \in Ri​=j,k∈R.

To see this, denote FFF and F′F'F′ the sets before and after the replacement respectively. F=F′F = F'F=F′ implies that each point xxx belonging to FFF belongs to F′F'F′, and vice-versa. Specifically, the row replacement corresponds to left multiplying Aˉ\bar AAˉ by a matrix

E(i,j),k≐[11...k1...1]\begin{aligned} E_{(i,j), k} \doteq \left[ \begin{matrix} 1 & \\ & 1 \\ & & \quad... \\ & & k & 1 \\ & & & & ... \\ & & & & & 1 \end{matrix} \right] \end{aligned} E(i,j),k​≐⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎡​1​1​...k​1​...​1​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎤​​

which is a diagonal matrix with an additional kkk in the (i,j)(i, j)(i,j) position. It is invertible with inverse matrix

E(i,j),−k≐[11...−k1...1]\begin{aligned} E_{(i,j), -k} \doteq \left[ \begin{matrix} 1 & \\ & 1 \\ & & \quad... \\ & & -k & 1 \\ & & & & ... \\ & & & & & 1 \end{matrix} \right] \end{aligned} E(i,j),−k​≐⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎡​1​1​...−k​1​...​1​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎤​​

The previous claim becomes {x:E(i,j),kAx=E(i,j),kb}={x:Ax=b}\{ x : E_{(i, j), k} A x = E_{(i, j), k} b \} = \{ x : A x = b \}{x:E(i,j),k​Ax=E(i,j),k​b}={x:Ax=b}.

But wait. Why do we subtract the last row from the second one? Fact 1 has justified the replacement operation on Aˉ\bar AAˉ, but not on the objective coefficients ccc (the last row in the tabular form). To illustrate the meaning of the operation, recall that

x1+x2+0⋅s1+0⋅s2=zx_1 + x_2 + 0 \cdot s_1 + 0 \cdot s_2 = z x1​+x2​+0⋅s1​+0⋅s2​=z

Hence zzz is the value of the objective function. After normalizing the second row, it becomes

x1+1/2x2+0s1+1/2s2=3x_1 + 1 / 2 x_2 + 0 s_1 + 1/2 s_2 = 3 \\ x1​+1/2x2​+0s1​+1/2s2​=3

The constraint holds for any feasible point of the linear programming. Therefore,

z−3=(x1+x2+0s1+0s2)−(x1+1/2x2+0s1+1/2s2)=0x1+1/2x2+0s1−1/2s2⇔z=0x1+1/2x2+0s1−1/2s2+3\begin{aligned} z - 3 &= (x_1 + x_2 + 0 s_1 + 0 s_2) - (x_1 + 1 / 2 x_2 + 0 s_1 + 1/2 s_2) \\ &= 0x_1 + 1/2x_2 + 0s_1 - 1/2 s_2 \\ &\Leftrightarrow \\ z &= 0x_1 + 1/2x_2 + 0s_1 - 1/2 s_2 + 3 \end{aligned} z−3z​=(x1​+x2​+0s1​+0s2​)−(x1​+1/2x2​+0s1​+1/2s2​)=0x1​+1/2x2​+0s1​−1/2s2​⇔=0x1​+1/2x2​+0s1​−1/2s2​+3​

The last −3-3−3 in the table is the inverse constant in the objective functions after the replacement of variable.

Back to our search

To improve the current solution further, we note that the coefficient of x2x_2x2​ is positive. We can increase the value of x2x_2x2​. The maximum increase is given by min⁡{3/(1/2),3/(3/2)}=2\min \{ 3 / (1 / 2), 3 / (3/ 2) \} = 2min{3/(1/2),3/(3/2)}=2, determined by the first row:

03/21−1/2∣311/201/2∣301/20−1/2∣−3\begin{aligned} 0 && 3/2 && 1 && -1/2 && \mid 3 \\ 1 && 1/2 && 0 && 1/2 && \mid 3 \\ \hline 0 && 1/2 && 0 && -1/2 && \mid -3 \\ \end{aligned} 010​​3/21/21/2​​100​​−1/21/2−1/2​​∣3∣3∣−3​​

To make the change explicitly, we perform elimination by the first row

012/3−1/3∣210−1/32/3∣200−1/3−1/3∣−4\begin{aligned} 0 && 1 && 2/3 && -1/3 && \mid 2 \\ 1 && 0 && -1/3 && 2/3 && \mid 2 \\ \hline 0 && 0 && -1/3 && -1/3 && \mid -4 \\ \end{aligned} 010​​100​​2/3−1/3−1/3​​−1/32/3−1/3​​∣2∣2∣−4​​

which give solution x=(2,2,0,0)x = (2, 2, 0, 0)x=(2,2,0,0) and objective value 444. It is indeed optimal solution for the problem, as all coefficients of the optimization are non-positive.

Optimality Condition and Strong Duality

We investigate the result deeper by viewing the initial tabular form in abbreviation as

[AI∣bcT0∣0]\left[ \begin{matrix} A \quad I \mid b \\ c^T \quad 0 \mid 0 \end{matrix} \right] [AI∣bcT0∣0​]

The series of mmm Gaussian elimination can be interpreted as left multiplying a matrix:

[R0−yT1]≐Em...E3E2E1\begin{aligned} \left[ \begin{matrix} & R & 0 \\ & -y^T & 1 \\ \end{matrix} \right] \doteq E_m...E_3 E_2 E_1 \end{aligned} [​R−yT​01​]≐Em​...E3​E2​E1​​

where each EjE_jEj​ ( 1≤j≤m1 \le j \le m1≤j≤m) matrix is invertible and represents a Gaussian elimination, i.e., if we left multiple a matrix by EjE_jEj​, it is equivalent to perform Gaussian elimination on the matrix. The matrix product Em...E3E2E1E_m...E_3 E_2 E_1Em​...E3​E2​E1​ has the form

[R0−yT1]\begin{aligned} \left[ \begin{matrix} & R & 0 \\ & -y^T & 1 \\ \end{matrix} \right] \end{aligned} [​R−yT​01​]​

because we never use the last row to eliminate the other rows.

Now:

[R0−yT1][AI∣bcT0∣0]=[RAR∣Rb−yTA+cT−yT∣−yTb]\begin{aligned} \left[ \begin{matrix} & R & 0 \\ & -y^T & 1 \\ \end{matrix} \right] \left[ \begin{matrix} & A & I \mid b \\ & c^T & 0 \mid 0 \end{matrix} \right] = \left[ \begin{matrix} & RA & R & \mid & Rb \\ & -y^TA+c^T & -y^T &\mid & -y^T b \end{matrix} \right] \end{aligned} [​R−yT​01​][​AcT​I∣b0∣0​]=[​RA−yTA+cT​R−yT​∣∣​Rb−yTb​]​

In our example,

1210∣62101∣61100∣0⇒...⇒012/3−1/3∣210−1/32/3∣200−1/3−1/3∣−4\begin{aligned} 1 && 2 && 1 && 0 && \mid 6 \\ 2 && 1 && 0 && 1 && \mid 6 \\ \hline 1 && 1 && 0 && 0 && \mid 0 \\ \end{aligned} \Rightarrow ... \Rightarrow \begin{aligned} 0 && 1 && 2/3 && -1/3 && \mid 2 \\ 1 && 0 && -1/3 && 2/3 && \mid 2 \\ \hline 0 && 0 && -1/3 && -1/3 && \mid -4 \\ \end{aligned} 121​​211​​100​​010​​∣6∣6∣0​​⇒...⇒010​​100​​2/3−1/3−1/3​​−1/32/3−1/3​​∣2∣2∣−4​​

we have

R=[2/3−1/3−1/32/3]yT=[−1/3,−1/3]R = \begin{aligned} \left[ \begin{matrix} 2 / 3 & -1 / 3 \\ -1 / 3 & 2 /3 \end{matrix} \right] \end{aligned} \qquad y^T = [ -1 / 3, -1 / 3] R=[2/3−1/3​−1/32/3​]​yT=[−1/3,−1/3]

The optimality condition of simplex algorithm implies that

−yTA+cT≤0yT≤0yTb=cTx\begin{aligned} -y^T A + c^T &\le 0 \\ y^T &\le 0 \\ y^T b &= c^T x \end{aligned} −yTA+cTyTyTb​≤0≤0=cTx​

This is the optimal solution for the dual program of the primal:

min⁡ bTy,s.t.,ATy≥c,yT≥0\min \ b^T y, \qquad s.t., A^T y \ge c, \quad y^T \ge 0 min bTy,s.t.,ATy≥c,yT≥0

If simplex algorithm stops, it implies strong duality holds:

  • The optimal value of the primal program equals to the optimal one of the dual program, assuming that both values exist and are bounded.

Geometric Interpretation

In the beginning we claim that the simplex algorithm move from one vertex to another. We prove it rigorously in this section. First we need a few definitions:

Vertex

A vertex is a point v∈Fv \in Fv∈F, such that ∄v1,v2∈F,v1≠v2\nexists v_1, v_2 \in F, v_1 \neq v_2∄v1​,v2​∈F,v1​​=v2​ and λ∈(0,1)\lambda \in (0, 1)λ∈(0,1), s.t., v=λv1+(1−λ)v2v = \lambda v_1 + (1 - \lambda) v_2v=λv1​+(1−λ)v2​.

In other words, vvv is a vertex of FFF if it is not contained in a line segment of PPP.

Theorem. If LP has an optimal solution, then it has an optimal solution that is a vertex of its feasible set.

Proof. Denote vvv the optimal solution of the LP with maximum number of zero components. If vvv is not a vertex, then ∃v1,v2≠v,v1,v2∈F\exists v_1, v_2 \neq v, v_1, v_2 \in F∃v1​,v2​​=v,v1​,v2​∈F and λ>0\lambda > 0λ>0, such that λv1+(1−λ)v2=v\lambda v_1 + (1 - \lambda) v_2 = vλv1​+(1−λ)v2​=v.

As vvv is optimal, we have cTv≥cTv1c^T v \ge c^T v_1cTv≥cTv1​ and cTv≥cTv2c^T v \ge c^T v_2cTv≥cTv2​. By λv1+(1−λ)v2=v\lambda v_1 + (1 - \lambda) v_2 = vλv1​+(1−λ)v2​=v, it concludes that cTv=cTv1=cTv2c_T v = c^T v_1 = c^T v_2cT​v=cTv1​=cTv2​.

Define I={i:v[i]>0}I = \{ i : v[i] > 0 \}I={i:v[i]>0}. As v1≥0,v2≥0v_1 \ge 0, v_2 \ge 0v1​≥0,v2​≥0 and λv1+(1−λ)v2=v\lambda v_1 + (1 - \lambda) v_2 = vλv1​+(1−λ)v2​=v so that for i≠Ii \neq Ii​=I, v1[i]=v2[i]=v[i]=0v_1[i] = v_2[i] = v[i] = 0v1​[i]=v2​[i]=v[i]=0.

But AIv1[I]=AIv2[I]=bA_I v_1[I] = A_I v_2[I] = bAI​v1​[I]=AI​v2​[I]=b. Let x=ϵ(v1−v2)+vx = \epsilon (v_1 - v_2) + vx=ϵ(v1​−v2​)+v.

  1. xxx is feasible, for small enough ϵ\epsilonϵ.
  2. xxx is optimal, since cTx=ϵcT(v1−v2)+cTv=cTvc^T x= \epsilon c^T (v_1 - v_2) + c^T v = c^T vcTx=ϵcT(v1​−v2​)+cTv=cTv.
  3. xi=0x_i = 0xi​=0 for i∉Ii \notin Ii∈/​I.

We can find some ϵ\epsilonϵ (either positive or false) to make xi=0x_i = 0xi​=0 for some i∈Ii \in Ii∈I. Now xxx contains more zeros than vvv, a contradiction. □\square□

Basic Solution

A solution xxx of Ax=bAx = bAx=b is called a basic solution if {Ai:xi≠0}\{A_i : x_i \neq 0 \}{Ai​:xi​​=0} (columns in AAA that correspond to non-zero components in xxx ) are linearly independent.

Basic Feasible Solution

A basic solution xxx is called basic feasible solution if x≥0x \ge 0x≥0, i.e., x∈{x:Ax=b}∩{x≥0}x \in \{ x : Ax = b\} \cap \{ x \ge 0 \}x∈{x:Ax=b}∩{x≥0}.

With respect to the feasible region of LP in slack form, the vertices have have following property:

Lemma:. A point v∈F={x:Ax=b}∩{x:x≥0}v \in F = \{x : Ax = b\} \cap \{ x: x \ge 0\}v∈F={x:Ax=b}∩{x:x≥0} is a vertex of FFF if and only if it is a basic feasible solution. Here A∈Rm×n,x∈Rn,b∈RmA \in R^{m \times n}, x \in R^n, b \in R^{m}A∈Rm×n,x∈Rn,b∈Rm and rank(A)=mrank(A) = mrank(A)=m (otherwise some row constraints of the Ax=bAx = bAx=b are redundant).

Proof: Denote SSS the set of indices of positive components in vvv and ASA_SAS​ the set of

Only if: If ASA_SAS​ does not have full column rank, then ∃u∈R∣S∣\exists u \in R^{|S|}∃u∈R∣S∣, such that ASu=0A_S u = 0AS​u=0. Then for small enough ϵ∈R,ϵ>0\epsilon \in R, \epsilon > 0ϵ∈R,ϵ>0,
both v+ϵuv + \epsilon uv+ϵu and v−ϵuv - \epsilon uv−ϵu are feasible point in FFF. Now v=0.5(v+ϵu)+0.5(v−ϵu)v = 0.5(v + \epsilon u) + 0.5(v - \epsilon u)v=0.5(v+ϵu)+0.5(v−ϵu), a contradiction.

If: As columns of ASA_SAS​ are linearly independent, the only solution of to ASxS=0A_S x_S = 0AS​xS​=0 is given by xS=0x_S = 0xS​=0. Hence, vSv_SvS​ is now the unique solution to ASvS=bA_S v_S = bAS​vS​=b. If vvv is not a vertex, ∃v1,v2,λ\exists v_1, v_2, \lambda∃v1​,v2​,λ, such that v=λv1+(1−λ)v2v = \lambda v_1 + (1 - \lambda) v_2v=λv1​+(1−λ)v2​. But in this case we must have v1=v2=vv_1 = v_2 = vv1​=v2​=v, as (v1)S=(v2)S=vS(v_1)_S = (v_2)_S = v_S(v1​)S​=(v2​)S​=vS​ and (v1)Sˉ=(v2)Sˉ=vSˉ=0(v_1)_{\bar S} = (v_2)_{\bar S} = v_{\bar S} = 0(v1​)Sˉ​=(v2​)Sˉ​=vSˉ​=0. A contradiction.

■\blacksquare■.

Corollary: The simplex algorithm moves from vertex to vertex.

Proof: The positive components in the solution correspond to the columns in the identity matrix in the tabular form of simplex, which are linearly independent.

Correctness of Simplex (TO FINISH)

Though not shown in the example, there are two issue associated with simplex algorithm.

  1. How do we find an initial solution? If there are negative component in bbb, then x=0∧s=bx = 0 \wedge s = bx=0∧s=b is not a feasible solution.
  2. How do we guarantee that simplex terminates?

In the previous example, at each step we choose to increase the variable with largest coefficient. In some rare cases, this results in a loop of the algorithm.

One method for avoiding looping is called Bland’s rule:

  1. If there is a positive coefficient in the objective function, choose the one with largest coefficient.
  2. If there are multiple rows with tight constraints, choose the one with largest coefficient.

Theorem. Blands’ rule guarantees that the algorithm stops.

Proof. Suppose that on the contrary, the algorithm loops. Denote B1,B2,...,BkB_1, B_2, ..., B_kB1​,B2​,...,Bk​ the set of basis in the loop. In each base, there is entering variable and one leaving variable. Every variable that leaves the base must enter another base later. We called these variable fickle variables. Denote xtx_txt​ the fickle variable with the largest index.

  1. DDD the dictionary that xtx_txt​ leaves the base, and xex_exe​ the variable that enters the base.
  2. D′D'D′ the dictionary that xtx_txt​ enters the base again.

D=IAN∣b0cN∣α⇒...⇒D′=RRAN∣RbyTyTAN+cN∣yTb+αD = \begin{aligned} I && A_N && \mid b \\ \hline 0 && c_N && \mid \alpha \\ \end{aligned} \Rightarrow ... \Rightarrow D' = \begin{aligned} R && R A_N && \mid R b \\ \hline y^T && y^T A_N + c_N && \mid y^T b + \alpha \\ \end{aligned} D=I0​​AN​cN​​​∣b∣α​​⇒...⇒D′=RyT​​RAN​yTAN​+cN​​​∣Rb∣yTb+α​​

We have

ce′=ce+yTAN[:,e]c_e' = c_e + y^T A_N[:, e] ce′​=ce​+yTAN​[:,e]

  1. xex_exe​ is the entering variable in DDD, therefore ce>0c_e > 0ce​>0.
  2. xtx_txt​ is the entering variable in D′D'D′, and e<te < te<t, by the definition of xtx_txt​, we have xe′≤0x_e' \le 0xe′​≤0.
  3. Hence, yTAN[:,e]=ce′−ce<0y^T A_N[:, e] = c_e' - c_e < 0yTAN​[:,e]=ce′​−ce​<0.
  4. ∃i,s.t.,yiAi,e<0\exists i, s.t., y_i A_{i, e} < 0∃i,s.t.,yi​Ai,e​<0. Then yi≠0y_i \neq 0yi​​=0, and xix_ixi​ is fickle. By definition, i<ti < ti<t. But xix_ixi​ is not entering D′D'D′, we know that yi<0y_i < 0yi​<0.
  5. Ai,e>0A_{i, e} > 0Ai,e​>0. But since xix_ixi​ is fickle, we have bi=0b_i = 0bi​=0. In this case, xix_ixi​ is chosen in preference to xtx_txt​. A contradiction.

Reference

[1]. Dantzig, George B. “Origins of the simplex method.” A history of scientific computing. 1990. 141-151.

LP - Dual Program, Weak Duality, Complementary Slackness, Strong Duality

Posted on 2020-01-30 Edited on 2020-02-01

Dual Program and Weak Duality

Linear programming studies the optimization problems in which both its objective function and feasible region are represented by linear relationship.

Every linear program can be converted into Canonical form

max⁡cTxs.t.,Ax≤bx≥0\begin{aligned} & \max & c^T x \\ & s.t., & Ax \le b \\ && x \ge 0 \end{aligned} ​maxs.t.,​cTxAx≤bx≥0​

where c,x∈Rnc, x \in \mathcal{R}^nc,x∈Rn, A∈Rm×nA \in \mathcal{R}^{m \times n}A∈Rm×n and b∈Rmb \in \mathcal{R}^mb∈Rm.

Suppose we have a conic combination (y∈Rmy \in \mathcal{R}^my∈Rm and y≥0y \ge 0y≥0) of the linear constraints:

yT(Ax)≤yTby^T (Ax) \le y^T b yT(Ax)≤yTb

Such that yTA≥cTy^T A \ge c^TyTA≥cT, then yTby^T byTb gives an upper bound of the original program. We want to find a yyy, such that the bound is as tight as possible. This gives rise to another linear program:

min⁡yTbs.t.,yTA≥cTy≥0\begin{aligned} & \min & y^T b \\ & s.t., & y^T A \ge c^T \\ && y \ge 0 \end{aligned} ​mins.t.,​yTbyTA≥cTy≥0​

We call the original program the primal and the derived program its dual.

The philosophy of dual program is to use the combination of primal constraints to construct a bound of its objective function. More formally, the goal is that the weak duality holds:

cTx≤(yTA)x=yTAx=yT(Ax)≤yTbc^T x \le (y^T A) x = y^T A x = y^T (Ax) \le y^T b cTx≤(yTA)x=yTAx=yT(Ax)≤yTb

Note that cTx≤(ATy)Txc^T x \le (A^T y)^T xcTx≤(ATy)Tx is true because yTA≥cy^T A \ge cyTA≥c and x≥0x \ge 0x≥0. And yT(Ax)≤yTby^T (Ax) \le y^T byT(Ax)≤yTb follows from Ax≤bAx \le bAx≤b and yT≥0y^T \ge 0yT≥0.

Corollary 1: If the primal is unbounded, then the dual is infeasible. If the dual is unbounded, then the primal is infeasible.

In general, the primal may not be given in Canonical form and can be formulated as

max⁡cTx+cˉTxˉ+c^Tx^s.t.,Ax+Aˉxˉ+A^x^≤bBx+Bˉxˉ+B^x^=bˉCx+Cˉxˉ+C^x^≥b^x≥0x^≤0\begin{aligned} & \max & c^T x + \bar c^T \bar x + \hat c^T \hat x \\ & s.t., & Ax + \bar A \bar x + \hat A \hat x \le b \\ && Bx + \bar B \bar x + \hat B \hat x = \bar b \\ && Cx + \bar C \bar x + \hat C \hat x \ge \hat b \\ && x \ge 0 \\ && \hat x \le 0 \end{aligned} ​maxs.t.,​cTx+cˉTxˉ+c^Tx^Ax+Aˉxˉ+A^x^≤bBx+Bˉxˉ+B^x^=bˉCx+Cˉxˉ+C^x^≥b^x≥0x^≤0​

Note that the xˉ\bar xxˉ's are unconstrained variables. Guided by similar philosophy, we hope to derive an upper bound by using the constraints:

cTx+cˉTxˉ+c^Tx^≤yT(Ax+Aˉxˉ+A^x^)+yˉT(Bx+Bˉxˉ+B^x^)+y^T(Cx+Cˉxˉ+C^x^)≤yTb+yˉTbˉ+y^Tb^\begin{aligned} c^T x + \bar c^T \bar x + \hat c^T \hat x & \le y^T (Ax + \bar A \bar x + \hat A \hat x) \\ & + \bar y^T (Bx + \bar B \bar x + \hat B \hat x) \\ & + \hat y^T (Cx + \bar C \bar x + \hat C \hat x) \\ &\le y^T b + \bar y^T \bar b + \hat y^T \hat b \end{aligned} cTx+cˉTxˉ+c^Tx^​≤yT(Ax+Aˉxˉ+A^x^)+yˉ​T(Bx+Bˉxˉ+B^x^)+y^​T(Cx+Cˉxˉ+C^x^)≤yTb+yˉ​Tbˉ+y^​Tb^​

  1. The first inequality implies that (by proper rearranging):

    cTx+cˉTxˉ+c^Tx^≤(yTA+yˉTB+y^TC)x+(yTAˉ+yˉTBˉ+y^TCˉ)xˉ+(yTA^+yˉTB^+y^TC^)x^\begin{aligned} c^T x + \bar c^T \bar x + \hat c^T \hat x & \le (y^T A + \bar y^T B + \hat y^T C)x \\ & + (y^T \bar A + \bar y^T \bar B + \hat y^T \bar C) \bar x \\ & + (y^T \hat A + \bar y^T \hat B + \hat y^T \hat C) \hat x \end{aligned} cTx+cˉTxˉ+c^Tx^​≤(yTA+yˉ​TB+y^​TC)x+(yTAˉ+yˉ​TBˉ+y^​TCˉ)xˉ+(yTA^+yˉ​TB^+y^​TC^)x^​

    As x≥0x \ge 0x≥0, xˉ\bar xxˉ unconstrained and x^≤0\hat x \le 0x^≤0, a sufficient condition for the inequality to become true is

    cT≤(yTA+yˉTB+y^TC)cˉT=(yTAˉ+yˉTBˉ+y^TCˉ)c^T≥(yTA^+yˉTB^+y^TC^)\begin{aligned} c^T & \le (y^T A + \bar y^T B + \hat y^T C) \\ \bar c^T & = (y^T \bar A + \bar y^T \bar B + \hat y^T \bar C) \\ \hat c^T & \ge (y^T \hat A + \bar y^T \hat B + \hat y^T \hat C) \\ \end{aligned} cTcˉTc^T​≤(yTA+yˉ​TB+y^​TC)=(yTAˉ+yˉ​TBˉ+y^​TCˉ)≥(yTA^+yˉ​TB^+y^​TC^)​

    That gives the first set of constraints the dual variables yyy, yˉ\bar yyˉ​ and y^\hat yy^​ need to satisfies. We have just seen that the sign of the primal variable determines the type of constraint in the dual.

    Of particular interest is the inequality constraint, which we will dive into details in the next section.

  2. By similar argument, the second inequality is true if yT≥0y^T \ge 0yT≥0, yˉT\bar y^Tyˉ​T unconstrained, y^T≤0\hat y^T \le 0y^​T≤0. That is, the type of constraint in the primal determines the sign of variable in the dual.

Finally, the rules of obtaining dual are summarized as follows:

Primalmax⁡min⁡DualConstraints≤bi≥bi=bi≥0≤0Both sidesVariablesVariables≥0≤0Both sides≥cj≤ci=cjConstraints\begin{aligned} \hline &&& \text{Primal} &&& \max \quad &&& \qquad \qquad \min &&& \text{Dual} &&& \\ \hline &&& Constraints &&& \begin{matrix} \le b_i \\ \ge b_i \\ = b_i \end{matrix} \quad &&& \qquad \quad \begin{matrix} \ge 0 \\ \le 0 \\ \text{Both sides} \end{matrix} &&& Variables &&& \\ \hline &&& Variables &&&\qquad \begin{matrix} \ge 0 \\ \le 0 \\ \text{Both sides} \end{matrix} &&& \qquad \qquad \begin{matrix} \ge c_j \\ \le c_i \\ = c_j \end{matrix} &&& Constraints &&& \\ \hline \end{aligned} ​​​PrimalConstraintsVariables​​​max≤bi​≥bi​=bi​​≥0≤0Both sides​​​​min≥0≤0Both sides​≥cj​≤ci​=cj​​​​​DualVariablesConstraints​​​​​

Complementary Slackness

The strong duality states that, if both primal and dual are feasible, then the objective function values of their optimal solutions equal.

If we expand the weak duality expression for the standard form, we get

∑i=1ncixi≤∑i=1n(∑j=1myjAi,j)xi=∑j=1myj(∑i=1nAi,jxi)≤∑j=1myjbj\sum_{i = 1}^n c_i x_i \le \sum_{i = 1}^n \left( \sum_{j = 1}^m y_j A_{i, j} \right) x_i = \sum_{j = 1}^m y_j \left( \sum_{i = 1}^n A_{i, j} x_i \right) \le \sum_{j = 1}^m y_j b_j i=1∑n​ci​xi​≤i=1∑n​(j=1∑m​yj​Ai,j​)xi​=j=1∑m​yj​(i=1∑n​Ai,j​xi​)≤j=1∑m​yj​bj​

Then cTx=yTbc^T x= y^T bcTx=yTb implies

∑i=1ncixi=∑i=1n(∑j=1myjAi,j)xi∑j=1myj(∑i=1nAi,jxi)=∑j=1mbjyj\sum_{i = 1}^n c_i x_i = \sum_{i = 1}^n \left( \sum_{j = 1}^m y_j A_{i, j} \right) x_i \\ \sum_{j = 1}^m y_j \left( \sum_{i = 1}^n A_{i, j} x_i \right) = \sum_{j = 1}^m b_j y_j i=1∑n​ci​xi​=i=1∑n​(j=1∑m​yj​Ai,j​)xi​j=1∑m​yj​(i=1∑n​Ai,j​xi​)=j=1∑m​bj​yj​

i.e.,

∑i=1n(∑j=1myjAi,j−ci)xi=0∑j=1myj(bj−∑i=1nAi,jxi)=0\sum_{i = 1}^n \left( \sum_{j = 1}^m y_j A_{i, j} - c_i \right) x_i = 0\\ \sum_{j = 1}^m y_j \left( b_j - \sum_{i = 1}^n A_{i, j} x_i \right) = 0 i=1∑n​(j=1∑m​yj​Ai,j​−ci​)xi​=0j=1∑m​yj​(bj​−i=1∑n​Ai,j​xi​)=0

As ∑j=1mAi,jyj−ci≥0\sum_{j = 1}^m A_{i, j} y_j - c_i \ge 0∑j=1m​Ai,j​yj​−ci​≥0, xi≥0x_i \ge 0xi​≥0 for all iii and bj−∑i=1nAi,jxi≥0b_j - \sum_{i = 1}^n A_{i, j} x_i \ge 0bj​−∑i=1n​Ai,j​xi​≥0 and yj≥0y_j \ge 0yj​≥0 for all jjj, we conclude that

∑j=1myjAi,j−ci=0∨xi=0∀ibj−∑i=1nAi,jxi=0∨yj=0,∀j\begin{aligned} &\sum_{j = 1}^m y_j A_{i, j} - c_i = 0 &\vee && x_i = 0 & \forall i \\ &b_j - \sum_{i = 1}^n A_{i, j} x_i = 0 &\vee && y_j = 0, & \forall j \end{aligned} ​j=1∑m​yj​Ai,j​−ci​=0bj​−i=1∑n​Ai,j​xi​=0​∨∨​​xi​=0yj​=0,​∀i∀j​

Or more compactly

(yTA−cT)x=0yT(b−Ax)=0(y^T A - c^T) x = 0 \\y^T (b - Ax) = 0 (yTA−cT)x=0yT(b−Ax)=0

If the primal is in canonical form, then the fact that AT≥c,x≥0,y≥0,b−Ax≥0A^T \ge c, x \ge 0, y \ge 0, b - Ax \ge 0AT≥c,x≥0,y≥0,b−Ax≥0 implies that

(yTA−cT)i=0∨xi=0∀ iyj=0∨(b−Ax)j=0∀ j\begin{aligned} &(y^T A - c^T)_i = 0 &&\vee && x_i = 0 &&&\forall \ i \\ &y_j = 0 &&\vee && (b - Ax)_j = 0 &&&\forall \ j \end{aligned} ​(yTA−cT)i​=0yj​=0​​∨∨​​xi​=0(b−Ax)j​=0​​​∀ i∀ j​

where (yTA−cT)(y^T A - c^T)(yTA−cT) is a vector and (yTA−cT)i(y^T A - c^T)_i(yTA−cT)i​ is its iii-th coordinate.

This is known as complementary slackness.

Strong Duality

Question to ponder: what is the geometric interpretation of complementary slackness?

Special Case

To illustrate its underlying meaning, first consider the special case

min⁡yTbs.t.,yTA=cT\begin{aligned} & \min & y^T b \\ & s.t., & y^T A = c^T \end{aligned} ​mins.t.,​yTbyTA=cT​

whose dual form is given by

max⁡cTxs.t.,Ax=b\begin{aligned} & \max & c^T x \\ & s.t., & Ax = b \end{aligned} ​maxs.t.,​cTxAx=b​

First note that yTA=cTy^T A = c^TyTA=cT means that cTc^TcT is a linear combination of rows of AAA. The primal is feasible if ccc is in the row space of AAA.

In this special case, if both primal and dual are feasible, then for any feasible solutions xxx and yyy, strong duality holds, since cTx=(yTA)x=yT(Ax)=yTbc^T x = (y^T A) x = y^T (Ax) = y^T bcTx=(yTA)x=yT(Ax)=yTb.

The dual search for some xxx such that

Ax=bAx = b Ax=b

If we can find such xxx, it implies that bbb lies in the column space of AAA, denoted as C(A)C(A)C(A) (the subspace in Rn\mathcal{R}^nRn spanned by the row vectors of AAA). What if not? We can decompose bbb into two part: b=b1+b2b = b_1 + b_2b=b1​+b2​, such that b1∈C(A)b_1 \in C(A)b1​∈C(A) and 0≠b2∈N(AT)0 \neq b_2 \in N(A^T)0​=b2​∈N(AT) (the subspace orthogonal to C(A)C(A)C(A)). Here is the problem: if yyy is a feasible solution for the primal, then we can decrease yyy by arbitrary amount along the direction orthogonal to C(A)C(A)C(A), while maintaining its feasibility. In particular, if we add k⋅b2k \cdot b_2k⋅b2​ to yyy (k>0k > 0k>0), then (y−kb2)(y - k b_2)(y−kb2​) is still feasible as (y−kb2)TA=yTA−kb2TA=cT(y - k b_2)^T A = y^T A - k b_2^T A = c^T(y−kb2​)TA=yTA−kb2T​A=cT. But now (y−k⋅b2)Tb=yTb−kb2Tb2<yTb(y - k \cdot b_2)^T b = y^T b - k b_2^T b_2 < y^T b(y−k⋅b2​)Tb=yTb−kb2T​b2​<yTb, which implies that the primal is unbounded.

General Case

Now we return our discussion to the more general form:

min⁡yTbs.t.,yTA≥cT\begin{aligned} & \min & y^T b \\ & s.t., & y^T A \ge c^T \end{aligned} ​mins.t.,​yTbyTA≥cT​

Its dual is given by

max⁡cTxs.t.,Ax=bx≥0\begin{aligned} & \max & c^T x \\ & s.t., & Ax = b \\ && x \ge 0 \end{aligned} ​maxs.t.,​cTxAx=bx≥0​

Every LP can be converted into standard form.

The weak duality states that

cTx≤yTAx=yTbc^T x \le y^T A x = y^T b cTx≤yTAx=yTb

If both primal and dual are feasible, then strong duality reduce to show that the first inequality holds with equality, that is, ∃\exists∃ feasible x,yx, yx,y, s.t., cTx=yTAxc^T x = y^T A xcTx=yTAx. In particular, complementary slackness, this is equivalent to proving that

(yTA−cT)i=0∨xi=0∀ i\begin{aligned} &(y^T A - c^T)_i = 0 &&\vee &&x_i = 0 &&\forall \ i \\ \end{aligned} ​(yTA−cT)i​=0​​∨​​xi​=0​​∀ i​

We begin by assuming that yyy is the optimal solution for the dual. We claim that yyy can not be an interior point of the feasible region. Otherwise, yyy can move along arbitrary direction by a little while maintaining feasibility. If it moves along the direction pointed by −b-b−b, then the objective function value decreases, contradicting yyy being optimal.

Therefore, yyy must be on the boundary of the feasible region.

Question to ponder: prove the existence of optimal solution of the primal, assuming feasibility of the dual.

The boundary yyy touches are specified by tight constraints. The intuition behind is that, bbb must be the positive combination of the normal vector of the tight constraints. Otherwise, we can find some direction that decreases objective function value while maintaining feasibility.

Denote S⊂[m]S \subset [m]S⊂[m] the set of indexes, such that ∀i∈S\forall i \in S∀i∈S, yTAi=ciy^T A_i = c_iyTAi​=ci​, where AiA_iAi​ is the iii-th column of matrix AAA and cic_ici​ is the iii-th coordinator of vector ccc. In other words, SSS is the set of indexes for which the inequality is tight.

We claim that bbb is in the conic hull of columns of AsA_sAs​. That is, ∃xS∈R∣S∣\exists x_S \in R^{|S|}∃xS​∈R∣S∣, such that

  1. ASxS=bA_S x_S = bAS​xS​=b.
  2. xS≥0x_S \ge 0xS​≥0.

Such xSx_SxS​ gives a feasible solution to the primal, by setting xSˉ=0x_{\bar S} = 0xSˉ​=0 and x=xS∪xSˉx = x_S \cup x_{\bar S}x=xS​∪xSˉ​. Further, strong duality holds as cTx=yTAx=yTbc^T x = y^T A x = y^T bcTx=yTAx=yTb.

Proof:

It suffices to show that bbb is a conic combination of columns of ASA_SAS​. Suppose not. Then by Farkas’ Lemma, ∃v∈Rm\exists v \in \R^m∃v∈Rm, such that

  1. vTAS≥0v^T A_S \ge 0vTAS​≥0.
  2. vTb<0v^T b < 0vTb<0.

Then we can move the vector yyy along the direction of vvv. But this time we need to be careful, in order not to violate the constraints.

For each inequality constraint yTAi>ciy^T A_i > c_iyTAi​>ci​ (i∈Sˉi \in \bar Si∈Sˉ), ∃ti>0\exists t_i > 0∃ti​>0, such that (y+tiv)TAi>ci(y + t_i v)^T A_i > c_i(y+ti​v)TAi​>ci​. Denote t=min⁡i∈Sˉtit = \min_{i \in \bar S} t_it=mini∈Sˉ​ti​.

As (y+tv)TAS=cS+tvTAS≥cS(y + t v)^T A_S = c_S + t v^T A_S \ge c_S(y+tv)TAS​=cS​+tvTAS​≥cS​, (y+tv)(y + t v)(y+tv) is still feasible. But (y+tv)Tb<yTb(y + t v)^T b < y^T b(y+tv)Tb<yTb. A contradiction.

Question to ponder: relate the above discussion to Lagrange multiplier and K.K.T condition.

Reference.

  1. David P. Williamson, ORIE 6300 Mathematical Programming I, Lecture 8
  2. Boyd, S. and Vandenberghe, L., 2004. Convex optimization. Cambridge university press.

Sparse Recovery with Count-Sketch

Posted on 2020-01-14 Edited on 2020-01-15

Suppose that a stream of items comes online S={a1,a2,...,am}S = \{ a_1, a_2, ..., a_m \}S={a1​,a2​,...,am​} where ai∈[n]a_i \in [n]ai​∈[n]. Denote the frequency of SSS as f=<f1,f2,...,fn>f = <f_1, f_2, ..., f_n>f=<f1​,f2​,...,fn​>, where fj=∣{ai∈S:ai=j}∣f_j = |\{ a_i \in S : a_i = j \}|fj​=∣{ai​∈S:ai​=j}∣. By running the count-sketch algorithm, we can obtain an estimation f^\hat ff^​ of fff with space O(1ϵ2log⁡n)O(\frac{1}{\epsilon^2} \log n)O(ϵ21​logn), such that with high probability, for i∈[n]i \in [n]i∈[n],

∣f^i−fi∣≤ϵ∣f∣2|\hat f_i - f_i| \le \epsilon |f|_2 ∣f^​i​−fi​∣≤ϵ∣f∣2​

where ∣f∣2=∑i=1nfi2|f|_2 = \sqrt {\sum_{i = 1}^n f_i^2 }∣f∣2​=∑i=1n​fi2​​.

In general, a sketch is a concise representation of fff. Suppose that we limit our space usage to kkk words (i.e., ∣f^∣0=k|\hat f|_0 = k∣f^​∣0​=k), and assume that HHH is the set of items of kkk most frequent items, then the sketch f^\hat ff^​ that minimize the l2l_2l2​ error keeps all items in HHH and the error between fff and f^\hat ff^​ is

∣f−f^∣2≐err2k(f)=∑i∈Hfi2|f - \hat f|_2 \doteq err_2^k (f) = \sqrt {\sum_{i \in H} f_i^2} ∣f−f^​∣2​≐err2k​(f)=i∈H∑​fi2​​

In practice, however, SSS is not given offline. As we don’t know HHH, we can only compute an f^\hat ff^​ with kkk words that is as good as possible. The question is, how far ∣f−f^∣2|f - \hat f|_2∣f−f^​∣2​ can be from the minimum possible value, namely err2k(f)err_2^k(f)err2k​(f)?

One possible solution, proposed by Cormode and Muthukrishnan [1], is to construct f^\hat ff^​ vis Count-Sketch with d=O(log⁡n)d = O(\log n)d=O(logn) hash tables each of which has size w=3kϵ2w = \frac{3k}{\epsilon^2}w=ϵ23k​.

Lemma 1. For any i∈[n]i \in [n]i∈[n], we have ∣fi−f^i∣≤ϵkerr2k(f)|f_i - \hat f_i| \le \frac{\epsilon}{\sqrt k } err_2^k(f)∣fi​−f^​i​∣≤k​ϵ​err2k​(f) with high probability.

Proof
Denote hj(i)h_j(i)hj​(i) the value of item iii in the jjj-th hash table. Let AiA_iAi​ be the event such that any of the kkk items with largest frequency is hashed to position hj(i)h_j(i)hj​(i) in the jjj-th table. Then by union bound,

Pr⁡[Ai]≤kw=ϵ23\Pr[A_i] \le \frac{k}{w} = \frac{\epsilon^2}{3} Pr[Ai​]≤wk​=3ϵ2​

Now,

Pr⁡[∣fi−hi(j)∣≥ϵkerr2k(f)]=Pr⁡[∣fi−hi(j)∣≥ϵkerr2k(f)∣Ai]+Pr⁡[∣fi−hi(j)∣≥ϵkerr2k(f)∣Aˉi]≤Pr⁡[Ai]+Var[fi−hi(j)∣Aˉi](ϵkerr2k(f))2≤ϵ23+(err2k(f))2w(ϵkerr2k(f))2≤ϵ23+13\begin{aligned} \Pr[|f_i - h_i(j)| \ge \frac{\epsilon}{\sqrt k } err_2^k(f) ] &= \Pr[|f_i - h_i(j) | \ge \frac{\epsilon}{\sqrt k } err_2^k(f) \mid A_i ] + \Pr[|f_i - h_i(j) | \ge \frac{\epsilon}{\sqrt k } err_2^k(f) \mid \bar A_i ] \\ &\le \Pr[A_i] + \frac{ Var[ f_i - h_i(j) \mid \bar A_i ] }{ (\frac{\epsilon}{\sqrt k } err_2^k(f) )^2 } \\ &\le \frac{\epsilon^2}{3} + \frac{(err_2^k(f))^2}{ w (\frac{\epsilon}{\sqrt k } err_2^k(f) )^2 } \\ &\le \frac{\epsilon^2}{3} + \frac{1}{3} \end{aligned} Pr[∣fi​−hi​(j)∣≥k​ϵ​err2k​(f)]​=Pr[∣fi​−hi​(j)∣≥k​ϵ​err2k​(f)∣Ai​]+Pr[∣fi​−hi​(j)∣≥k​ϵ​err2k​(f)∣Aˉi​]≤Pr[Ai​]+(k​ϵ​err2k​(f))2Var[fi​−hi​(j)∣Aˉi​]​≤3ϵ2​+w(k​ϵ​err2k​(f))2(err2k​(f))2​≤3ϵ2​+31​​

As long as ϵ2/3<1/6\epsilon^2 / 3 < 1 / 6ϵ2/3<1/6, this probability is smaller than 1/21 / 21/2. We can boost the failure probability to 1/n21/ n^21/n2 by repeating the hash tables d=O(log⁡n)d = O(\log n)d=O(logn) times and taking the median as estimation.

■\blacksquare■

The next step is keep only set H^\hat HH^ of the kkk largest items in f^\hat ff^​. Note that H^\hat HH^ might not equals to HHH. To bound the value ∣f−f^∣2|f - \hat f|_2∣f−f^​∣2​, we divide [n][n][n] into three subsets: H^\hat HH^, H∖H^H \setminus \hat HH∖H^, and [n][n][n]\setminus (H \cup \hat H)$

Lemma 2. ∑i∈H^(fi−f^i)2≤ϵ2(err2k(f))2\sum_{i \in \hat H} (f_i - \hat f_i)^2 \le \epsilon^2 (err_2^k(f))^2∑i∈H^​(fi​−f^​i​)2≤ϵ2(err2k​(f))2.

Proof. As ∣H^∣=k|\hat H| = k∣H^∣=k, this follow directly from lemma 1.

■\blacksquare■

Lemma 3. ∑i∈H∖H^fi2≤∑j∈H^∖Hf^j2+(2ϵ+ϵ2)(err2k(f))2\sum_{i \in H \setminus \hat H} f_i ^2 \le \sum_{j \in \hat H \setminus H} \hat f_j^2 + (2 \epsilon + \epsilon^2) ( err_2^k(f))^2∑i∈H∖H^​fi2​≤∑j∈H^∖H​f^​j2​+(2ϵ+ϵ2)(err2k​(f))2

Proof. ∣H∣=∣H^∣|H| = |\hat H|∣H∣=∣H^∣, we have ∣H∖H^∣=∣H^∖H∣|H \setminus \hat H| = |\hat H \setminus H|∣H∖H^∣=∣H^∖H∣.

If H∖H^=∅H \setminus \hat H = \emptysetH∖H^=∅, the claim is trivial. Otherwise, we can construct a bijection between H∖H^H \setminus \hat HH∖H^ and H^∖H\hat H \setminus HH^∖H. Then for i∈H∖H^i \in H \setminus \hat Hi∈H∖H^,

fi=fi−f^i+f^i−f^j+f^jf_i = f_i - \hat f_i + \hat f_i - \hat f_j + \hat f_j fi​=fi​−f^​i​+f^​i​−f^​j​+f^​j​

As H^\hat HH^ contains the largest kkk items in f^\hat ff^​, it must be that f^i−f^j≤0\hat f_i - \hat f_j \le 0f^​i​−f^​j​≤0. Therefore,

fi≤fi−f^i+f^jf_i \le f_i - \hat f_i + \hat f_j fi​≤fi​−f^​i​+f^​j​

By lemma 1, we have fi−f^i≤ϵkerr2k(f)f_i - \hat f_i \le \frac{\epsilon}{\sqrt k } err_2^k(f)fi​−f^​i​≤k​ϵ​err2k​(f), we have

fi≤ϵkerr2k(f)+f^jf_i \le \frac{\epsilon}{\sqrt k } err_2^k(f) + \hat f_j fi​≤k​ϵ​err2k​(f)+f^​j​

Summing over all possible iii,

∑i∈H∖H^fi2≤∑j∈H^∖H(ϵkerr2k(f)+f^j)2=∑j∈H^∖Hf^j2+2(∑j∈H^∖Hf^j)ϵkerr2k(f)+ϵ2(err2k(f))2≤∑j∈H^∖Hf^j2+2k∑j∈H^∖H1kf^j2ϵkerr2k(f)+ϵ2(err2k(f))2=∑j∈H^∖Hf^j2+2ϵ(err2k(f))∑j∈H^∖Hf^j2+ϵ2(err2k(f))2≤∑j∈H^∖Hf^j2+(2ϵ+ϵ2)(err2k(f))2\begin{aligned} \sum_{i \in H \setminus \hat H} f_i ^2 &\le \sum_{j \in \hat H \setminus H} (\frac{\epsilon}{\sqrt k } err_2^k(f) + \hat f_j)^2 \\ &= \sum_{j \in \hat H \setminus H} \hat f_j^2 + 2 \left( \sum_{j \in \hat H \setminus H} \hat f_j \right) \frac{\epsilon}{\sqrt k } err_2^k(f) + \epsilon^2 ( err_2^k(f))^2 \\ &\le \sum_{j \in \hat H \setminus H} \hat f_j^2 + 2 k \sqrt{ \sum_{j \in \hat H \setminus H} \frac{1}{k} \hat f_j^2} \frac{\epsilon}{\sqrt k } err_2^k(f) + \epsilon^2 ( err_2^k(f))^2 \\ &= \sum_{j \in \hat H \setminus H} \hat f_j^2 + 2 \epsilon (err_2^k(f)) \sqrt{ \sum_{j \in \hat H \setminus H} \hat f_j^2} + \epsilon^2 ( err_2^k(f))^2 \\ &\le \sum_{j \in \hat H \setminus H} \hat f_j^2 + (2 \epsilon + \epsilon^2) ( err_2^k(f))^2 \end{aligned} i∈H∖H^∑​fi2​​≤j∈H^∖H∑​(k​ϵ​err2k​(f)+f^​j​)2=j∈H^∖H∑​f^​j2​+2⎝⎛​j∈H^∖H∑​f^​j​⎠⎞​k​ϵ​err2k​(f)+ϵ2(err2k​(f))2≤j∈H^∖H∑​f^​j2​+2kj∈H^∖H∑​k1​f^​j2​​k​ϵ​err2k​(f)+ϵ2(err2k​(f))2=j∈H^∖H∑​f^​j2​+2ϵ(err2k​(f))j∈H^∖H∑​f^​j2​​+ϵ2(err2k​(f))2≤j∈H^∖H∑​f^​j2​+(2ϵ+ϵ2)(err2k​(f))2​
